Authors: Yunus U., Willyarto M.N., Wahyuningtyas B.P., Anindito, Amelia C.A.
Title: Raising customer experience to maintain loyalty (Case Study: Tinkerlust.com)
Source title: Proceedings of 2020 International Conference on Information Management and Technology, ICIMTech 2020
Affiliations: Cross-Cultural Communication, Research Interest Group, Bina Nusantara University, Faculty of Economics Communication, Marketing Communication Program, Communication Department, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Bina Nusantara University, Faculty of Humanities, Language Center, Industrial Engineering Department, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Bina Nusantara University, Faculty of Economics Communication, Marketing Communication Program, Communication Department, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; School of Information Systems, Bina Nusantara University, Information Systems Department, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Yunus, U., Cross-Cultural Communication, Research Interest Group, Bina Nusantara University, Faculty of Economics Communication, Marketing Communication Program, Communication Department, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Willyarto, M.N., Bina Nusantara University, Faculty of Humanities, Language Center, Industrial Engineering Department, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Wahyuningtyas, B.P., Bina Nusantara University, Faculty of Economics Communication, Marketing Communication Program, Communication Department, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Anindito, School of Information Systems, Bina Nusantara University, Information Systems Department, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Amelia, C.A., Bina Nusantara University, Faculty of Humanities, Language Center, Industrial Engineering Department, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: This study had the purpose to prove and explore how customer experience could build loyalty. The method was mixed research methods with examining quantitative and qualitative data. The result showed that there was an influence between customer experience on seller loyalty Tinkerlust.com, the effect was 41, 2 percent. The sellers have sold at Tinkerlust at least three times or more. The conclusion in the element of experience that most make them loyal to the brand was a way of communication and sales system that met their expectations. This study was expected to be able to contribute to people to participate in protecting the environment in a way not consumptive in fashion shopping. © 2020 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Customer experience; Loyalty; Prelove fashion; Seller
Index Keywords: Information management; Customer experience; Qualitative data; Sales

Authors: Willyarto M.N., Werhoru D., Januarta S., Rivaldo
Title: Visual aid presentation as a learning method: A case study in learning English of management students in Binus University
Affiliations: Language Center, Industrial Engineering, Faculty of Humanities, Indonesia; Language Center, English Literature, Faculty of Humanities, Indonesia; Management Master Track, Binus Business School, Indonesia; Management Major, Faculty of Economics and Communication, Indonesia; Bina Nusantara University, Jl. Kebon Jeruk Raya No. 27, Kebon Jeruk Jakarta Barat, 11530, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Willyarto, M.N., Language Center, Industrial Engineering, Faculty of Humanities, Indonesia, Bina Nusantara University, Jl. Kebon Jeruk Raya No. 27, Kebon Jeruk Jakarta Barat, 11530, Indonesia; Werhoru, D., Language Center, English Literature, Faculty of Humanities, Indonesia, Bina Nusantara University, Jl. Kebon Jeruk Raya No. 27, Kebon Jeruk Jakarta Barat, 11530, Indonesia; Januarta, S., Management Master Track, Binus Business School, Indonesia, Bina Nusantara University, Jl. Kebon Jeruk Raya No. 27, Kebon Jeruk Jakarta Barat, 11530, Indonesia; Rivaldo, Management Major, Faculty of Economics and Communication, Indonesia, Bina Nusantara University, Jl. Kebon Jeruk Raya No. 27, Kebon Jeruk Jakarta Barat, 11530, Indonesia
Abstract: Schools, colleges and universities are now embracing the use of visual aid presentation (e.g., PowerPoint) in the classroom. Studies have consistently indicated that students generally believed that the use of technology for oral presentation would facilitate their learning. Students in such condition believed that the class was more organized, clear and interesting. Students also liked the teacher/lecturer more and indicated that they would like to take another class from the teacher/lecturer when the he or she used technology means of presentation. This research was focusing on the perspective of students in Binus University regarding the advantages or disadvantages of this model of learning process in regard of interesting or boring and long or short endurance of understanding. The visual aid presentation here meant that the students were the ones who were performing the presentation, instead of the teacher/lecturer. The research method used was descriptive qualitative based on the survey and interview of some sample students who were chosen randomly, who were taking English course in first/second semester.Based on some researches, the visual aid presentation in learning process was showing positive impact for teachers and students. Therefore, the hypothesis on this research was that the visual aid presentation on learning process would bring an interesting environment, long endurance of understanding and improving students' behavior. It was expected that the result of this research could be used to improve the learning method of English learning in Binus University in order to support Binus Vision to be a global university and to enrich graduates with the skill of oral presentation.The respondents were selected from management students in Binus, Alam Sutera Campus, and randomly chosen. All of the respondents replied that learning by doing presentations was giving more understanding on topics, boosting up self-confident, teaching public speaking, handling nervous and creating a dynamic class environment to avoid boredom. From the students' point of view, this learning method was giving advantage for students and long endurance of understanding. © Published under licence by IOP Publishing Ltd.
Index Keywords: Learning systems; Technical presentations; Colleges and universities; English Learning; Learning by doing; Learning English; Learning methods; Oral presentations; research methods; Students' behaviors; Students
Funding Details: Office of Technology Transfer and Procurement

Authors: Willyarto M.N., Yunus U., Reksodipuro A.S., Liawatimena S.
Title: Comparison road safety education with and without IoT to develop perceptual motor skills in early childhood children aged 4-5
Source title: Proceeding - 2019 International Conference of Artificial Intelligence and Information Technology, ICAIIT 2019
Affiliations: Language Center Industrial Engineering Department, Faculty of Humanities, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Research Interest Group Leader, Cross-Cultural Communication, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Special Needs Teacher, Support Center, Australian Independent School, Indonesia; Computer Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Willyarto, M.N., Language Center Industrial Engineering Department, Faculty of Humanities, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Yunus, U., Research Interest Group Leader, Cross-Cultural Communication, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Reksodipuro, A.S., Special Needs Teacher, Support Center, Australian Independent School, Indonesia; Liawatimena, S., Computer Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: One of the best ways to teach children about road safety in schools is through interactive learning by introducing them to the crossing signs. With the implementation of interactive learning activities regarding the introduction of the crossing signs, is expected to occur for increasing perceptual-motor skills of the research subjects. Perceptual-motor skills are associated with the ability to react quickly to any situations on the street. Through interactive learning activities, the subject research has shown their positive responses and enthusiasm in doing those activities. The research subject is ten preschool students aged 4-5. The process of data collection is conducted through observations, interviews, personal documents of the students, distributing the questionnaire to parents, as well as documentation such as photographs. The research was without IoT. The result of this research found out that the subject research's perceptual motor skills seemed to increase regarding the reaction of speed and correctness from their body movement toward the visual information given. This acquisition appears after the research subject were given some fun and hands-on activities at school especially about an introduction to the crossing signs for preschool children. It was recommended to use IoT for better achievement. © 2019 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Interactive learning; Internet of Things; Perceptual motor skills; Road safety

Authors: Willyarto M.N., Werhoru D., Gea A.A.
Title: The use of english in learning mathematics for grade 7 junior high school
Source title: Proceedings - 2017 International Symposium on Educational Technology, ISET 2017
Affiliations: Language Center, Primary Teacher Education Department, Faculty of Humanities, Bina Nusantara University, Indonesia; Language Center, English Department, Faculty of Humanities, Bina Nusantara University, Indonesia; Character Building Development Center, Information Systems Department, Bina Nusantara University, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Willyarto, M.N., Language Center, Primary Teacher Education Department, Faculty of Humanities, Bina Nusantara University, Indonesia; Werhoru, D., Language Center, English Department, Faculty of Humanities, Bina Nusantara University, Indonesia; Gea, A.A., Character Building Development Center, Information Systems Department, Bina Nusantara University, Indonesia
Abstract: There are still many people think that learning Mathematics in English causes students difficulty in obtaining a good score. Therefore, the authors conducted research related to the use of English in teaching Mathematics, for grade 7 junior high school in a private national plus school. The purpose of this study is for the reader to open up further insights related to the topic above. This research was carried out with experimental design, by doing different treatment between classes in the same level. The subjects of the study consisted of 63 students spread into 3 classes, 7 Amos, Esther 7 and 7 Jonah. Class 7 Jonah is a control group, using Bahasa Indonesia (mother tongue) in learning Mathematics. Class 7 Amos and 7 Esther is the experimental group, where 7 Amos in English and 7 Esther used bilingual (English and Indonesian). Results of the study include the following: the use of English is not detrimental to the students in score acquisition, is evident from the class treated differently, giving an average final score of Mathematics that are not significantly different. The obstacles that arise in learning Mathematics needs to be reviewed from the process, readiness, independence, motivation of students and needs to be followed up critically so that students can achieve good results. Programs of short and long term needs to be created and observed in order to support the learning process of Mathematics for students, such as training teachers to be able to speak English, training teachers to teach Mathematics, especially for young children, to support action research by teachers, managed by the school. © 2017 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Educational technology; Mathematical techniques; Personnel training; Students; Teaching; Action research; Different treatments; English; Experimental groups; Junior high schools; Learning; Learning Mathematics; Learning process; Education

Authors: Benawa A., Gea A.A., Willyarto M.N.
Title: Improving teacher’s commitment by improving external factors
Affiliations: CBMKU Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Benawa, A., CBMKU Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Gea, A.A., CBMKU Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Willyarto, M.N., CBMKU Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Abstract: This article was written base on our research, which obtain the information that there is direct positive effect of organizational culture, leadership, work environment, and organization trust as the external factors on the organizational commitment. By quantitative approach our research used a survey method by structured interview with a sample of 75 teachers. The data collected were processed by path analyses. The result showed that the organizational commitment was effected directly positive by the external factors, i.e., organizational culture, leadership, work environment, and trust. The implication is the teacher’s organizational commitment can be increased by improving the organizational culture, leadership, work environment and trust as the external factors. © 2017 American Scientific Publishers All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Leadership; Organizational commitment; Organizational culture; Trust; Work environment
References: Colquitt, J.A., Lepine, J.A., Wesson, M.J., (2011) Organizational Behavior: Improving Performance and Commitment in the Workplace, 69, p. 66. , McGraw-Hill, New York; Robbins, S.P., Judge, T.A., (2011) Organizational Behavior, p. 145. , Prentice Hall, New Jersey; Colquitt, J.A., Lepine, J.A., Wesson, M.J., (2011) Organizational Behavior: Improving Performance and Commitment in the Workplace, pp. 557, 451, 219. , McGraw-Hill, New York; Nyhan, R.C., (1999) Review of Public Personnel Administration, 19, p. 58; Perry, R.W., (2004) Review of Public Personal Administration, 24, p. 133; Ingersoll, G.L., Kirsch, J.C., Merck, S.E., Lightfoot, J., (2000) Journal Nurse Administration, 30, p. 11; Williams, E.S., Rondeau, K.V., Francescutti, L.H., (2007) Leadership in Health Services, 20, p. 158; Slocum, J.W., Hellriegel, D., (2007) Principles of Organizational Behavior, South Western, p. 328; Canessa, E., Riolo, R.L., (2003) Computational and Mathematical Organization Theory, 9, p. 147; Lok, P., Crawford, J., (2004) Journal of Management Development, 23, p. 321; Walumbwa, F.O., Orwa, B., Wang, P., Lawler, J.J., (2005) Human Resource Development Quarterly, 16, p. 235; Yousef, D.A., (2000) Journal of Managerial Psychology, 15, p. 6; Avolio, B.J., Zhu, W., Koh, W., Bhatia, P., (2004) Journal of Organizational Behavior, 25, p. 951; McCormick, E.J., Tiffin, J., (2004) Industrial Psychology, p. 465. , Prentice Hall, New Jersey; Kürşad, Y., (2008) Journal of Applied Sciences, 8, p. 2293

Authors: Willyarto M.N., Pane M., Chairiyani R.
Title: Mathematics learning method of bar modeling for elementary school students
Authors with affiliations: Willyarto, M.N., Bina Nusantara University11530, Indonesia; Pane, M., Bina Nusantara University11530, Indonesia; Chairiyani, R., Bina Nusantara University11530, Indonesia
Abstract: Discrepancy of knowledge among students, teachers and schools to some extent has contributed in developing the negative attitude that says mathematics is hard. Therefore, the author tries to explain a method for teaching mathematics (especially for elementary school students), to be easily understood by students. As a result, mathematics is no longer perceived hard. One good method of learning mathematics is the use of models (bar modeling). The author conducted research by providing two different treatments, without bar modeling and with bar modeling, to the elementary school students. The result showed that the use of bar modeling has increased students’ scores significantly. Bar modeling is not the only method of teaching at the elementary level, and it is easier for elementary school students in learning mathematical concepts of symbolization in problem solving. © 2015 American Scientific Publishers.
